As a former patron (when there was little choice) of "roach coaches," I have little patience for the new food trucks. I see the appeal, for the entrepreneur: low start up costs, low operating costs, portability, etc. But where is the advantage for the customer? The prices are similar to a low end cafe, without: bathrooms, tables, wait staff, free water, air conditioning, seats. So what's the appeal? Novelty and a chance to stand in line staring at one's telephone? Not for me, thanks.

Ignorance and lack of political involvement acts to the detriment of the relative have-nots.  Such willful disengagement is disempowering.

Rational government is conducted to gain and maintain the consent of the governed. It really is futile to try to govern people who see no merit to subordinating one or more of their own interests to the collective for the benefit of all.

Mr. Bruni's faith in the government about which he wishes we were all better informed is charming. What makes him think that government, if we should care, cares back? People are nice to people who are nice to them. Our government provides land for us to live on and regulations to keep us in line and paying taxes. But where is the "polity" -- that quaint Greek notion -- that would inspire this furrow-browed learning Mr. Bruni so wants to see? E pluribus unum? Ask the arms builders feeding at the public trough and the politicians who carry their water. There is unity among them, the haves. They keep the system working for their benefit.

The ignorance among the (relative) have-nots that Mr. Bruni deplores may be a willful reaction, a not-so-blind ignorance. Maybe the know-nothings know more than Mr. Bruni suspects they do: maybe nobody much cares about them except as tax-paying subjects, not citizens, to be exploited. Oh, and, by all means, send their children and grandchildren off to fight in wars that the haves wouldn't dream of sending their offspring to fight in.

Mr. Bruni wants us to know MORE about those who govern us? Maybe we want to know even less.

You couldn't be more wrong Tim. They are sighted regularly off the coast of Kauai because it is closest (other than Niihau) to the largest population. But monk seals in the NW islands are underweight and forced to compete with other top-level predators who have overpopulated the NW islands like ulua and sharks. Also, NW pups are consistently weaned underweight because their mothers can't put on enough fat to nurse them long enough to allow them to survive their weaning and learning period. Monk seals nurse young for only a maximum of 7 weeks, far less than that in the NW, and they get no training from their mother in how to hunt or what to hunt. They have to figure all that out on their own while living off their nursing fat gained after birth.

Add to that the competition from other predators for the pups and very few make it to adulthood. Conversely, the seals in the Main Hawaiian Islands are healthier, nurse their pups longer and have less competition for food from other predators. There are currently about 150-200 in the MHI, in decreasing numbers per island from Kauai to Hawaii island.

I've volunteered with the Monk Seal Response Team for 8 years and have seen all kinds of seal/human interaction. Seals don't "close beaches" they merely require a zone of protection (you wouldn't believe what people try to do to sleeping seals, treating them like exhibits at Disneyland for their personal enjoyment).

Trenberth clearly means something different by "missing heat" than does the global warming denier's crowd. Trenberth means that the models can't account for deployment of all the energy that's being returned to the earth because of the greenhouse gas buildup. The deniers mean that the heat (energy) isn't coming in — CO2 and other greenhouse gases don't "warm" (energize) the earth system.

Concerning the remark:

"…the missing heat is trapped in the deep oceans and it will come back with a vengeance unless climate sinners repent by either trading their SUVs for a hybrid or purchasing carbon credits at a price > $30/ton."

Actually, the energy is and will continue to affect the climate system with a vengeance regardless or whether people buy hybrids or purchase carbon credits. Unfortunately, it's too late for such measures to make much, if any difference. What could happen — if we started to zero out out carbon emissions posthaste and complete that process within 20 years or so — is the avoidance of some of the worst effects of climate change.

But here it seems that the climate deniers have won the day. (Not won the future, however.) The chances of meaningful action on carbon reductions in the next few years are practically nil. The consequences of inaction are already occurring, and will continue to worsen until everyone but a few isolated cranks will understand what's happening. But by that time, there will be little that can be done to avoid catastrophic changes.

Yet another person who is displaying ignorance about the PPACA. There are approximately 50 million Americans who are uninsured. Most of them are employed and many of them are far from being "in need". You probably have friends and acquaintances who have been deemed "uninsurable" by the insurance companies for various reasons. They aren't asking for a hand out, just to be allowed to buy health insurance to reduce their risk of financial ruin due to causes beyond their control. I have a family member with a minor and common congenital heart problem. This is not a lifestyle issue. He has a thriving small business and makes a comfortable middle class living. He is completely healthy, but still is considered "uninsurable". If he were to get sick with some medical problem requiring extensive care, he could wind up spending much of his retirement savings -- and no, medical is not "free" in the ER, either.

George, you are quite simply ignorant about the realities of medical insurance in the U.S.

Given the relevance today, I'm surprised you haven't delved into the South's self-inflicted economic disaster. The Confederate Constitution barred economic efforts by the national government including rail lines.

It did nothing to join the many lines that went to the same town but did not meet. Iron was insufficient for existing rail lines and none to build new lines with. Only one short interstate line was finished between Danville, Va and Greensboro, NC as the war's end neared

Georgia Governor Joe Brown refused to allow George railcars out of his state. Not unusual.

Grant's campaign isolated Vicksburg and trapped the enemy there. He broke rail line in three states, defeating other threats in detail, and cut both supply lines and commercial routes by river and rail across the Midsouth. Grant understood Scott's Anaconda strategy.

Thanks to the cutoff of shipments of horses, cattle, pigs and food from the Trans-Mississippi, Lee's army was soon eating meat imported by eastern Blockade runners. Mobile became the only Confederal port on the gulf of any importance and it fell the next year.

In the East, apart from Lee, Grant ordered seizure of Fort Fisher and Wilmington; accomplished.

Two great commanders met in Virginia. In a year, Grant had defeated the Great Robert E. Lee, always attacking, never stepping back and in doing so, he annihilated Lee's army and wreaked total defeat on the Confederacy. It was pretty, but it was decisive.

Diana makes an excellent point here.  Sadly, communications professionals (previously PR liaisons or, in earlier lingo, 'flacks') are increasingly controlling public discourse to the point of distorting events.  This is, sadly, a bipartisan problem-- it is practiced throughout Washington, both by official bodies and by trade associations.  Even worse, substantive policy decisions are being substantially influenced by their 'communications impact', with substantive results accorded diminished priority in decision-making.  All told, communications has been accorded an outsized place in Washington policy and governance, to the detriment of the American people and the public welfare.  Again, this is a bipartisan problem.
